description: From Middle French épique, from Latin epicus, from Ancient Greek ἐπικός (epikós), from ἔπος (épos, “word, story”).

adjectives.description: epic (comparative more epic, superlative most epic)

entries.meaning: Of or relating to an epic.
Momentously heroic; grand in scale or character
examples: The epic defense was rewarded with the highest military decorations

entries.meaning: (colloquial, slang, informal) Extending beyond the usual or ordinary.
examples: The after-prom party was truly epic.

entries.meaning: An extended narrative poem in elevated or dignified language, celebrating the feats of a deity, demigod (heroic epic), other legend or traditional hero.
examples: The Icelandic epic took all night to recite.

entries.meaning: A series of events considered appropriate to an epic.
examples: The book was an epic in four volumes.

entries.meaning: (computing) In software development, a large or extended user story.
examples: Epics are shown in a separate list from user stories. This is because it is the user stories that are developed, not epics. Epics are decomposed into child user stories.

description: From epi-, from Ancient Greek ἐπί (epí, “on top of”).

entries.meaning: (category theory, of a morphism) That is an epimorphism.
